Highly selective synthesis of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid at mild conditions catalyzed by boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts Ji-Fan Li ⁎ Lei Zhao Juling Li Mengjie Li Chun-Ling Liu ⁎ Rong-Zhen Yang Wen-Sheng Dong ⁎ Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, PR China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU) MOE School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi Normal University Xi’an 710062 PR China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Cu/ZrO2 has been recently demonstrated as a promising non-precious metal catalyst for the efficient hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL), while suffering from insufficient catalytic activity and stability with relatively high reaction temperature (up to 200 °C). Herein, a series of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts modified with boron oxide was prepared and applied for hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The introducing boron oxide effectively improved the activity and lifespan of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst for hydrogenation of LA into GVL. The optimal 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst afforded complete LA conversion along with 100% GVL yield at 150 °C low temperature. Besides, 3BCu/ZrO2 showed outstanding long-term stability and ran stably with GVL yield up to 90% for at least 100 h in continuous fix-bed tests, making it a promising catalyst of industrial applications for LA hydrogenation. Furthermore, the boron oxide doped and free Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were fully characterized by using ICP, BET, N2O titration, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR/TPD, and NH3-TPD. Boron oxide strongly interacted with surface copper species, which in turn restrained the aggregation of copper particles and improved the copper dispersion during thermal treatment and reaction. The strong interaction of boron oxide with surface copper species mainly accounted for the excellent catalytic activity and stability of boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. Besides, doping boron oxide also increased specific surface area, modulated distribution of surface Cu0 and Cu+, facilitated adsorption of H2, and improved surface acidity of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, which also played positive roles on the catalytic activity. Keywords Cu/ZrO2catalysts γ-Valerolactone Levulinic acid Boron oxide 1 Introduction Levulinic acid (LA) is a pivotal platform molecule in many biorefinery schemes [1,2], because it can be obtained readily and cost-effective from acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of lignocellulosics with high yield, meanwhile, abundant high value-added chemicals, including γ-valerolactone (GVL), valeric acid, 1,4-pentanediol, nonanone, and 2-methyl-tetrahydrofuran, can be derived from LA [1,3–5]. The conversion of LA to GVL is considered as one of the promising and pivotal reactions to convert lignocellulose-based biomass into renewable fuels and chemicals, due to the wide range of applications of GVL. GVL can be applied as gasoline blend, food additive, green solvent, and a precursor to a variety of monomers [6–12]. Supported Ru, Rh, Pd, and Ir precious metal catalysts have been extensively employed for the hydrogenation of LA into GVL [13–20]. Especially supported Ru catalysts were demonstrated to be high-efficient catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA into GVL, and afforded high yield of GVL. However, Ru species leached readily due to its poor interaction with supports [8]. It was also oxidized easily and had poor reusability [3]. Moreover, the high cost of noble metal catalysts may be the major obstacles to their industrial application in large scale. Except for the renewable of the feedstock, the catalysts also should better be derived from abundant elements for truly sustainable processes. Therefore, it is especially important to develop high-efficient catalysts using non-noble metals. Recently, a few non-noble metal catalysts have been reported to be effective for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [6–8,21,25,26]. The copper-based catalysts, which are generally considered to be active for the selective hydrogenation of CO bonds and relatively inactive for the hydrogenolysis of CC bonds [22–24], have been reported as prospecting candidates for the hydrogenation of LA into GVL [4,6–8,25–27]. Rode et al. [8] found that complete LA conversion and up to 90% GVL selectivity were achieved over Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with a relatively high loading of copper at 200 °C, 5 MPa H2 for 5 h, but apparent deactivation was observed for these copper-based catalysts. Fan et al. [4] proposed a Cu/ZrO2 catalyst using oxalate-gel coprecipitation, and full conversion along with 100% selectivity of LA to GVL was achieved at 200 °C. Hutchings et al. [6,26] investigated the effects of preparation parameters on the catalytic performance of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst for LA conversion into GVL in detail and further identified the catalytically active component of Cu/ZrO2. They concluded that reduced copper particles highly dispersed on the catalyst surface were the active component, while the copper species incorporated into zirconia lattice were inactive for the hydrogenation of LA into GVL. Thus, design a copper-based catalyst with low loading and high dispersion helped improve the catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of LA. Komandur et al. [27] investigated the performance of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst for the vapor phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL using a continuous fix bed reactor. LA conversion of 81% and GVL selectivity of 83% was obtained at 265 °C, however, serious deactivation after running for 20 h was observed. Although copper-based catalysts were demonstrated to be effective catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA into GVL, many drawbacks need to be overcome or improved. The key issues are the poor lifetime and thermal stability. As stated above, most of the copper-based catalysts employed for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL in previous reports revealed poor stability and were used at relatively high reaction temperatures (up to 200 °C for a bath reactor and 250 °C for a fix bed reactor), despite their high initial activity. Normally, highly dispersed copper nanoparticles were required to afford the great activity. However, the highly dispersed small copper nanoparticles would easily aggregate and deactivate during the reaction process, especially for high-temperature reaction, owing to the low Hüttig temperature of copper (134 °C) [22,28]. Therefore, finding practical routes to design copper-based catalysts with highly dispersed surface copper nanoparticles and low-temperature activity was supposed to be an important strategy for improving the catalytic activity and lifespan. Besides, LA was converted to GVL via two possible routes as supported by previous reports (Scheme 1 ) [6–8]. One involved the hydrogenation of LA to 4-hydroxypentanoic acid followed by dehydration and intramolecular esterification to GVL. The other initiated by acid catalytic dehydration of LA to from angelica lactone succeeded by hydrogenation of angelica lactone to GVL. Irrespective of the first or second pathways, the dehydration and intramolecular esterification by acid catalysis were included to generate GVL. Thus, besides metal active sites, the surface acidic sites were also essential for the catalytic conversion of LA to GVL. Hence, the modification of Cu/ZrO2 by effective additives needs to obtain both highly dispersed surface copper nanoparticles and suitable acidity for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. In this work, we designed a series of boron oxide modified Cu/ZrO2 with purposes to develop base metal copper catalysts with outstanding catalytic activity and lifetime for LA hydrogenation under mild conditions. Furthermore, multiple characterization techniques were employed to give insight into the promotional roles of boron oxide. The structure-performance relationship of these boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts for the LA hydrogenation to GVL was also discussed deeply. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Cu/ZrO2 catalyst was prepared by the co-precipitation method. A mixed solution containing 0.05 M Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O and 0.1 M Zr(NO3)3∙3H2O with a volume ratio of 1:1 was co-precipitated with 3 M ammonium hydroxide aqueous solution with stirring at room temperature and pH = 7. After that, the precipitate was aged for 6 h at room temperature, filtrated, washed with deionized water, and dried at 100 °C for 8 h to obtain Cu/ZrO2 precursor. The boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by the immersion method. The Cu/ZrO2 precursor was soaked in a boric acid solution for 8 h, followed by being dried for 12 h at 100 °C and calcined for 4 h at 400 °C. The obtained samples were denoted as xBCu/ZrO2, where the x stands for the weight contents of boron. Prior to the reaction, the prepared catalysts were reduced in H2 pressure at 300 °C for 12 h. 2.2 Characterization The chemical compositions of catalysts were determined by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Icap 6300, USA). The N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were tested at Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M system. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on an Axis Ultra, Kratos (UK) system. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Rigaku D/MAX2550VB X-ray diffractometer. The H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and N2O titration were conducted on an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a mass spectrometry detector. For H2-TPR tests, 50 mg catalyst was loaded into a U-type quartz tube and heated to 500 °C at 10 °C/min in a 10%H2/90%Ar flowing. For H2-TPD experiments, prior to H2 adsorption, the sample was pre-reduced at 10%H2/90%Ar at 300 °C for 12 h and then cooled to 50 °C. Afterward, 10%H2/90%Ar flow was continued for 30 min adsorption, then the system was purged with pure Ar for 30 min to remove physisorbed H2 and heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. For NH3-TPD tests, the samples were pretreated in He at 400 °C for 1 h, then cooled to 100 °C and saturated with NH3, followed by being purged with He at 100 °C for 30 min and heated to 700 °C in He flow at a rate of 10 °C/min. N2O titration was carried out to detected the copper surface area [22]. The samples were pretreated by the H2-TPR program, and then oxidized by N2O flow for 2 h at 80 °C. After that, the sample was re-reduced using the same H2-TPR program. 2.3 Catalytic tests For the bath reaction, the reaction was conducted using an autoclave (35 mL). Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced by using H2 at 300 °C for 12 h. In a typical test, the autoclave was added with 1 ml levulinic acid, 0.2 g reduced catalyst, and 20 ml water solvent, and then sealed and purged 3 times with N2. Afterwards, the autoclave was pressurized to 3.0 MPa with H2 and heated to desired temperature with stirring for 5 h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled in an ice-water bath and depressurized. The liquid products were separated through filtration and analyzed by a high-performance liquid chromatography. The long-range performance of catalysts was conducted in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 12 mm. 1 g catalyst was placed into the isothermal region of the tubular reactor and two sides of catalyst bed were packed with quartz granules in a size range of 40–60 mesh. Before reaction, the catalyst was activated in H2 flowing with a rate of 40 ml/min at 300 °C for 12 h. Afterwards, the catalyst bed was cooled to 200 °C. A flow of H2 (40 ml/min) was fed and pressured to 3.0 MPa, followed by a 5 wt% levulinic acid aqueous solution being pumped into the reactor with a flowing rate of 0.05 ml/min. The liquid products were collected in an ice-water trap and also analyzed by a high-performance liquid chromatography. The conversion of levulinic acid was calculated using the following equations: (1) Levulinic acid conversion ( % ) = moles of converted levulinic acid moles of initial levulinic acid × 100, The yield of γ-valerolactone (GVL) was calculated using the following equation: (2) Y GVL ( % ) = moles of product GVL moles of initial levulinic acid × 100 , 3 Results 3.1 Characterizations of catalysts 3.1.1 Physicochemical properties of catalysts The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions (PSD) are displayed in Fig. 1 . All the Cu/ZrO2 and boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 samples displayed the features of both type I and IV isotherms with H4 type hysteresis loops (as shown in Fig. 1a), suggesting the co-existence of micropores and mesopores, while the hysteresis loop enlarged with the increase in the boron-doped contents illustrating the distribution of pore size broadened. Fig. 1b further confirmed that the pore size distribution widened as the content of boron increased. Moreover, The PSD shown in Fig. 1b suggested that all the samples contained a small amount of micropores besides a lot of mesopores, the contents of both the micropore and mesopore increased with increasing the boron oxide dopant. These results implied that the impregnation of boracic acid can create new pores during the calcination of samples. The detailed textural properties and chemical compositions of these catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The addition of boron into the Cu/ZrO2 catalyst significantly increased the specific surface area and pore volume, exhibiting a volcano-type variation tendency in terms of boron loading with maximum values at 3BCu/ZrO2. The average pore diameter also increased upon the introduction of boron. The increase in specific surface area and pore volume of boron-doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts was probably due to the creation of new pores caused by impregnation of boric acid, while the slight decrease in specific surface and pore volume of 5BCu/ZrO2 compared to 3BCu/ZrO2 could be ascribed to partial pore blockage caused by over-doped boron oxide [24,29]. The role of boric acid in pore creation and expansion was consistent well with the case of ordered mesoporous carbon [30–32], whose pore sizes could be tuned via using boric acid as a pore expanding agent. The impregnation of boric acid may corrode the frameworks of zirconium hydroxide in the dried powders of Cu/ZrO2 precursor, which would lead to the formation of abundant pores after calcination and consequent the increase in specific surface area. As shown in Table 1, the actual copper contents determined by ICP were slightly lower than the nominal values, because a little amount of copper was eluted in the washing procedure. Whereas the detected boron amounts were slightly higher than the designed values, which may be caused by the weight loss of copper in the dried powders of Cu/ZrO2 precursor. The dispersion, specific surface area and particle size of metallic copper in the reduced catalysts were measured by N2O titration (Table 1). The introduction of boron oxide into Cu/ZrO2 catalyst improved the copper dispersion and specific surface area noticeably, meanwhile decreased the particle size of copper remarkably. The highest copper dispersion (18.6%) and smallest copper particle size (5.3 nm) were achieved on 3BCu/ZrO2, nevertheless, further increasing boron oxide loading led to a mild decrease in dispersion and particle size of copper. It is believed that the doped boron species could interact with copper strongly and in turn impede the thermal transmigration and accumulation of copper nanoparticles in the calcination and reduction procedures, as a result, the copper dispersion was enhanced while the copper particle size decreased. [24,28,29]. However, the slight decline of 5BCu/ZrO2 in copper dispersion may be resulted from the partial coverage of copper surface by over-doped boron oxide. 3.1.2 Structural properties of catalysts Fig. 2 a displays the XRD patterns of catalysts calcined at 400 °C. The characteristic peaks of CuO phase at 35.5°, 38.7° and 48.5° (PDF#48-1548) were observed for the Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. With the introduction of boron oxide, the intensity of peaks for CuO phase deduced remarkably as the amount of boron oxide inclined, even the CuO species became undetectable on the 5BCu/ZrO2 catalysts. The particle size of CuO calculated based on the Scherrer equation also decreased in line with the content of boron oxide increased. The decrease in particle size of CuO evidenced by XRD fits well with observations of N2O titration, further confirming the promoting effect of boron oxide on the copper dispersion. No characteristic peaks of boron species were observed for all the samples, owing to high dispersion of boron species on the catalyst surface or the limited loading of boron species. Besides, a broad and diffuse peak at 32.5° was detected for all the samples, indicating the presence of amorphous ZrO2 [33]. Fig. 2b illustrates the XRD patterns of the reduced samples. Upon reduction at 300 °C for 12 h, the diffraction peaks of CuO disappeared, ZrO2 species remained in amorphization, while the peaks at 43.2°, 50.4° and 74.1° corresponded to metallic Cu (PDF#04-0836) appeared for all the reduced catalysts. In addition, a broad peak at about 19.5° was also observed for all the reduced samples, which was assigned to the paraffin used to prevent the oxidization of copper phase in reduced samples during exposure to air [29]. More importantly, the intensities of metallic copper diffraction peaks diminished gradually with the incorporation of boron oxide. The average particle size of metallic copper calculated by the Scherrer equation also decreased in a gradient from 22.9 nm for Cu/ZrO2 to 5.1 nm for 5BCu/ZrO2. Compared with that of CuO in each calcined catalyst, the particle size of Cu in the reduced catalyst grew up evidently, however, the increased extent showed a declined trend in term of the boron oxide doped amount. These results implied that copper species preferred to migrate and accumulate to larger particles in the calcination and reduction procedure. Whereas the impregnation of boron oxide was able to retard the aggregation of copper species upon the thermal treatment, and in turn decreased the particle size of copper species and improved their dispersion. 3.1.3 Surface chemical states The surface composition and chemical state of the reduced catalysts were distinguished via using XPS and XAES characterizations, the results are shown in Fig. 3 and summarized in Table 2 , respectively. As shown in Fig. 3a, the appearance of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p5/2 peaks at around 932.6 and 952.5 eV respectively, and the absence of satellite peaks at 940–950 eV suggested that almost all the surface Cu2+ species were reduced to Cu+ or Cu0 species upon reduction at 300 °C [23,24]. This agreed well with the results of XRD. The binding energy for Cu+ and Cu0 are normally undistinguishable by XPS, however, XAES can discriminate them effectively. Fig. 3b displays the Cu LMM XAES spectra, an asymmetry and broad peak was detected for all the samples and can be divided into two peaks located at about 916 and 918 eV, attributed to Cu+ and Cu0 species, respectively [22,23]. The deconvolution results listed in Table 2 revealed that the doping boron oxide significantly influenced the distribution of surface Cu+ and Cu0 species. The percent of Cu0 declined in line with the increase in boron oxide loading, which was related to the strong interaction between copper species and boron oxide. Their interaction would result in a low reduction degree and partial positive charge of surface copper species, because boron has a relatively high affinity for electrons for its high electronegativity. In Fig. 3c of the B 1 s spectra, peaks at 192.4 eV ascribed to B3+ were observed, no observable peak at 188.7 eV related to B0 was detected, suggesting that boron species were mainly presented in B3+. The intensity of B 1 s peak inclined gradually with the increase in boron oxide loading, indicating an rise in the amount of surface boron oxide species. Table 2 illustrated that the B/Cu atomic ratio determined via XPS was much higher than the values obtained from ICP analysis, further confirming the incline in the content of surface boron species and the surface enrichment of boron species. Fig. 3d displays the O 1s spectra of these catalysts. The O 1s profile for Cu/ZrO2 showed an asymmetric and broad peak lay from 528.9 to 535.2 eV and can be divided into two peaks centered at about 530.6 and 532.1 eV, respectively, indicating the existence of different O species. However, the O 1s profiles for the boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 samples presented asymmetric peaks with multiple shoulders or tailing peaks, which could be roughly deconvoluted into three peaks and denoted as α, β and γ, respectively. As shown in Fig. 3d, the designated α peak with the lowest binding energy may be attributed to the O species of ZrO2, the β peak with middle binding energy could be related to O species of Cu2O, while the γ peak with the highest binding energy can be ascribed to the O species of B2O3. The classification of these O 1s signals was in view of the difference in electronegativity of zirconium, copper and boron. The element with high electronegativity has an affinity for electrons, leading to electron-deficient O species with high binding energy. Thus, the highest binding energy of the O species in B2O3 was caused by the highest electronegativity of boron among zirconium, copper and boron. With the introduction of boron, the β and γ peaks in Fig. 3d rose obviously, further confirming that the enrichment of surface boron species and the elevation of Cu+ species with the increasing boron oxide loading. As listed in Table 2, with the addition of boron oxide, the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 moved gradually to higher values, while that of B 1 s declined. The variation in binding energy of Cu 2p and B 1 s reflected a transference of electron from copper species to boron species for the high electron affinity of boron [29], which was strongly indicative of the electron donor-acceptor interaction of copper with boron. 3.1.4 Reducibility, surface acidity and H2 adsorption To further investigate the interaction of copper species with boron species and the reducibility of these catalysts, H2-TPR experiments were carried out. As displayed in Fig. 4 , the TPR profile of Cu/ZrO2 showed a broad intensive peak ranging from 115 to 286 °C with a summit at 168 °C and a shoulder at 193 °C, indicating the presence of heterogeneous distribution of at least two different copper species [34–36]. With a view to clearly discriminate, the profile of Cu/ZrO2 was deconvoluted into two peaks which were denoted as α for the peak at low temperature and β for high-temperature peak, respectively. The α peak was contributed to the reduction of well-dispersed copper oxide species with small particle size, whereas β peak was ascribed to the reduction of copper oxides interacted strongly with support or with large particle size in the bulk [34,35]. All the boron oxide doped catalysts, except for 5BCu/ZrO2, displayed a broad asymmetric reductive peak with a shoulder or tail. Similarly, these TPR peaks also can be divided into two peaks, designated as α and β respectively. As clearly indicated in Fig. 4, the area of α peak amplified continuously whereas that of peak β diminished continuously with the increase of boron oxide introduced into the samples, even the border of α and β peaks became blurred and indivisible for 5BCu/ZrO2 catalyst. The incline of α peak was indicative of an increase in highly dispersed copper particles caused by introducing boron oxide, fitting well with the results of XRD and N2O adsorption. It resulted from the interaction of boron with copper oxide species on the ZrO2 surface, which retarded the mobility and aggregation of copper species on the ZrO2 surface in the thermal treatment procedure and in turn promote the formation of small copper oxide particles. Moreover, in comparison to the Cu/ZrO2 sample, these reduction peaks of boron oxide doped samples moved gradually to high temperature with the incline in the boron loading, no matter what α and β peak. It further confirmed the strong interactions of copper with boron species, in well line with the results of XPS. The surface acid properties the Cu/ZrO2 and boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were determined using NH3-TPD. As displayed in Fig. 5 , no apparent desorption of NH3 was detected for Cu/ZrO2, indicating the absence of detectable acid sites. As boron oxide was introduced into Cu/ZrO2 catalyst, the NH3-TPD profiles showed a wide peak centered at around 160 °C, furthermore, the desorption peak gradually elevated in area and meanwhile shifted slightly into higher temperature with the increase in boron oxide loading, suggesting the existence of weak acid sites on the boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts and their amount and strength was dependent on boron oxide loading. To our surprise, except for weak acid sites, a NH3 desorption peak at 520 °C represented strong acid sites was also observed for the 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst. Overall, NH3-TPD results demonstrated that doping boron oxide effectively improved the surface acid properties of Cu/ZrO2. Fig. 6 presents H2-TPD profiles of hydrogen adsorbed on the pre-reduced Cu/ZrO2 and boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. For the Cu/ZrO2 sample, the H2-TPD profile mainly presented two peaks centered at about 88 and 405 °C, respectively. The small peak with the low temperature at 88 °C originated from desorption of hydrogen species weakly adsorbed on the metal copper surface, which mostly included molecular hydrogen [37,38]. While the high-temperature peak resulted from desorption of hydrogen species strongly adsorbed on ZrO2 support, which was transported from the metal copper surface to ZrO2 via spillover [37,38]. With the introduction of boron oxide, the low-temperature peak ascribed to molecularly adsorbed hydrogen H2 diminished significantly, however, a broad shoulder peak emerged, which situated in the range of 185–337 °C on the left side of desorption peak for hydrogen spillover on ZrO2. The isolate metal Cu surface had limited ability in adsorbing and activating molecular hydrogen, in contrast, the Cu0-metals interface can facilitate the adsorption-activation of H2 and store atomic hydrogen as interval hydrogen [39,40]. As proved by XPS and H2-TPR results, boron oxide mainly presented on the catalyst surface and strongly interacted with copper species. Therefore, the shoulder peak at 185–337 °C observed for the boron oxide doped samples was ascribed to interval hydrogen species strongly adsorbed on the Cu-B2O3 interface, implying the significant enhancement in adsorption-activation of H2 by introducing boron oxide. Besides, the little sharp peak, which centered above 550 °C for the H2-TPD profiles of boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 samples, was probably due to desorption of hydrogen species adsorbed on bulk copper or boron oxide species. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalysts The Cu/ZrO2 and boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were employed for the production of GVL via hydrogenation of LA. Initially, all the samples were tested using water as a solvent at 200 °C for 5 h in a batch reactor, and the reaction results are presented in Table 3 . A complete selectivity of GVL was achieved for all the boron oxide doped and free Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, in well line with the previous reports [4,6,8]. Using water as a solvent was favorable for the highly selective production of GVL. A relatively low GVL yield of 31.4% was obtained for the boron oxide free Cu/ZrO2 catalyst, which was much lower than the 100% yield of GVL gained on Cu-ZrO2 catalyst in Rode’s previous work [8]. This was most presumably due to the much low loading of copper used in the present work. Nevertheless, the introduction of boron oxide into Cu/ZrO2 catalyst remarkably improved the catalytic performance. And with the increase in boron oxide loading, it presented a volcano-type performance in terms of LA conversion and GVL yield. Among these catalysts tested, the highest GVL yield of 100% was achieved on 3BCu/ZrO2, further increasing the amount of boron oxide doped led to a slight decline in both LA conversion and GVL yield. The declined catalytic activity obtained over 5BCu/ZrO2 was probably due to coverage of surface metallic copper active sites by overloading of boron oxide (Table 3). In view of the superior catalytic performance of 3BCu/ZrO2, a series of experiments with variation in reaction temperature were conducted to determine the lowest temperature for 3BCu/ZrO2 with a 100% yield of GVL. Fig. 7 shows the variation of LA conversion and GVL yield depended on the reaction temperature. As indicated in Fig. 7, the 100% yield of GVL can be achieved at a very low temperature of 150 °C for 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst, which is almost the lowest temperature ever reported for the copper-based catalysts with 100% GVL yield from LA hydrogenation. Moreover, an as high as 96.1% yield of GVL was obtained even at 140 °C. Though some other copper-based catalysts were reported to achieve good performances under mild reaction conditions [41,42], their mass activities were lower than that obtained for 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst, as shown in Table S1. These results clearly confirmed that 3BCu/ZrO2 exhibited the excellent catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL under mild conditions. The long-term stability and continuous operation are critical for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL for both academic and industrial standpoints. Thus, the long-term tests in a fix-bed reactor of the representative 3BCu/ZrO2 and boron oxide free Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were carried out, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 8 a. A serious deactivation within 25 h was observed for boron oxide free Cu/ZrO2, in contrast, 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited excellent performance and stabilized at least for 100 h long-term reaction with GVL yield above 90%, which was strongly indicative of its high stability and the potential for industrial applications. As shown in Fig. 8b, the particle size of metallic copper after running about 60 h for Cu/ZrO2 inclined obviously to 29.7 nm, in contrast, a much smaller particle of 16.2 nm was observed for the spent 3BCu/ZrO2 catalysts despite its longer running for 100 h. It strongly certified that addition boron oxide into Cu/ZrO2 prevented the serious aggregation of copper particles during the LA hydrogenation reaction. In addition, tetragonal and monoclinic ZrO2 were detected for both the spent Cu/ZrO2 and 3BCu/ZrO2 catalysts. The emergence of the tetragonal and monoclinic phase of ZrO2 was indicative of phase transformation of amorphous-to-tetragonal and -monoclinic during the reaction. However, a more serious phase transformation was observed for boron oxide free Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, as indicated by Fig. 8b. Thus, the addition of boron oxide could effectively control the growth of copper particle and phase transformation of ZrO2 support, which may be mainly responsible for the long-term stability of 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst. 4 Discussion 4.1 Influence of boron on catalytic activities The reduced copper particles on Cu-ZrO2 catalyst surface were demonstrated to be the catalytically active component for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [6]. Small copper nanoparticles on the catalyst surface were required to obtained high activity. In our case, copper species interacted strongly with boron oxide on the catalyst surface, contrarily, a relatively weak interaction formed between copper and ZrO2 supports, as evidenced by XPS and H2-TPR results. The strong interaction of copper species with boron oxide played a great role in hindering the coagulation and crystalline growth of copper species in the procedure of calcination, reduction and even reaction of LA hydrogenation, which was supported by the XRD analysis of calcined, reduced and spent catalysts. The restraining effect of boron oxide on the growth of copper particles was also found in the boron oxide doped Cu/SiO2 system [24,28,29]. Introducing a suitable loading of boron oxide can retard the growth of copper particles and in turn effectively improve the dispersion and surface area of reduced copper species simultaneously, however, the N2O titration results stated clearly that overloading of boron oxide evidently reduced the dispersion and surface area of surface copper in spite of the decrease in bulk copper particles determined by XRD. This phenomenon was caused by the cover of surface copper with over-doped boron oxide, because the additive of boron oxide preferred to enrich on the catalyst surface (as revealed by ICP and XPS results) and overdose of boron oxide will cover surface copper species, making it become inaccessible for N2O molecules. The diminution of the accessible copper surface was harmful to the catalytic performance. Among all the boron oxide doped and free Cu/ZrO2 tested in our work, 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst achieved the highest yield of GVL, meanwhile, it contained the best copper dispersion and largest copper surface area as determined by N2O titration. Clearly, the GVL yield strongly correlated with the copper dispersion on the catalyst surface. Thereby, the formation of highly dispersed copper nanoparticles induced by boron oxide doping played an important role in the catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. However, except for the copper surface area and dispersion, evident variations of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst caused by boron oxide doping included textural properties, reducibility, acidity, H2 adsorption and valence distribution of surface copper species (Cu0 and Cu+). Therefore, the other factors, which perhaps also influenced the catalytic behavior for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, cannot be ruled out. As supported by the earlier reports focused on the conversion of LA to GVL [3,6,8], the conversion mainly initiated by hydrogenation of ketone group in LA to generate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid, followed by dehydration and intramolecular esterification to form ring closure product GVL (Shown in Scheme 1). The cooperative effect of balanced Cu0 and Cu+ has been widely reported on the hydrogenation of ester, acyl and ketone groups for the copper-based catalysts [22–24]. The surface Cu0 sites were supposed to adsorb dissociatively hydrogen molecules, while surface Cu+ sites can strongly bond and activate CO in ester, acyl and ketone groups. As a result, the catalytic performance was in turn improved by the cooperative effect between Cu0 and Cu+. As revealed by XPS analysis results, boron oxide doped on the catalyst surface tended to induce an incline in the percentages of Cu+ and partial positive charges of Cu0, because boron had greater electronegativity and electron affinity than Zr. Thus, some active centers with optimized Cu0/Cu+ ratio modified by boron oxide doped may present to achieve a high hydrogenation activity, implying that the synergistic cooperation of surface Cu0 and Cu+ may be crucial for hydrogenation of ketone group in LA. In addition, the introduction of boron oxide would generate many Cu-B2O3 interfaces on the catalyst surface. The Cu-B2O3 interfaces were capable of adsorbing, activating molecular hydrogen, and storing atomic hydrogen in the form of interval hydrogen as evidenced by H2-TPD results. The considerable boost in the catalyst’s capability of adsorbing and activating H2 caused by boron oxide doping was also responsible for the improved catalytic performance [6]. An essential reaction step of dehydration and intramolecular esterification was included for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. It is well-known that surface acidity plays an important role in determining the activity of dehydration and esterification reactions [43,44]. Although Hutchings et al. [6] proposed that hydrogenation was the rate-limiting step for the LA conversion into GVL, the surface acidic sites were indispensable for the dehydration and intramolecular esterification of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid to form desired product GVL. Therefore, the improvement of the catalyst’s surface acidity induced by boron oxide doped was also beneficial to the catalytic conversion of LA to GVL. Besides, a dependence of GVL yield on the specific surface area in the Cu-ZrO2 catalyst system was demonstrated by Hutchings’ previous work [26]. In our work, a strong correlation between GVL yield and specific surface areas was also observed. 3BCu/ZrO2 achieved the best catalytic performance, and the highest value of the specific surface area of 232.9 m2/g was obtained coincidently. The positive effects of large specific surface area on the catalytic performance cannot be neglected, because large surface area and prosperous pore structure were favorable for the surface copper dispersion and mass transfer of reaction substrates. To sum up, the modulation of catalytic activity by doping boron oxide was multi-faceted. The optimal performance of 3BCu/ZrO2 was related to the combined contribution of the highest surface copper dispersion, synergistic effect of surface Cu0 and Cu+, facilitated adsorption of H2, the highest specific surface area together with the most acidic sites. The increasing Cu+ sites caused by doping boron oxide facilitated the adsorption and activation of CO groups of LA. Simultaneously, the small Cuo particles and Cu-B2O3 interfaces favored the activation of H2 to form dissociative H species. The active H species formed on small Cuo particles and Cu-B2O3 interfaces would attach the CO groups of LA adsorbed on Cu+ sites, and consequently generate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid intermediate. The 4-hydroxypentanoic acid underwent intramolecular esterification and dehydration over these acid sites derived from addition of boron oxide, and thus the formation of desired product of GVL was improved by doping boron oxide. 4.2 Influence of boron on catalyst stability It is well established that supported copper catalysts are readily to deactivate, which is mainly ascribed to the decrease of copper surface area and dispersion caused by the coagulation of surface copper particles for the low Hüttig (134 °C) temperature of copper [22,24,28,29,38]. As discussed in the XPS and H2-TPR sections, boron oxide enriched on the catalyst surface and strongly interacted with surface copper species. The strong interaction helped stabilize the active copper species and retard the aggregation and crystallite growth of small nanoparticles during LA hydrogenation confirmed by XRD analysis of calcined, reduced and spent catalysts, and resulting in excellent stability of 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst. Furthermore, ZrO2 support apparently underwent phase transformation of amorphous-to-tetragonal and -monoclinic during the reaction process of LA hydrogenation to GVL, as evidenced by the emergence of tetragonal and monoclinic ZrO2 in the spent catalysts. The frequent transition of ZrO2 support also probably induced the deactivation of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. On one hand, the relatively weak interaction between copper species and ZrO2 may be destroyed easily by the change in crystalline phase of ZrO2, which was harmful to thermal stability of the surface copper nanoparticles interacted with support and resulted in surface copper grain growth and deactivation of catalysts. On the other hand, Hutchings et al. [6] proposed that bulk copper species incorporated in ZrO2 support strongly interacted with surface reduced copper particles. This interaction facilitated the dissociation of molecular hydrogen and in turn improved the catalyst’s activity for LA hydrogenation. However, the phase transition of ZrO2 support may damage the interaction of bulk copper species with surface reduced copper particles, resulting in suppression of the hydrogen dissociated adsorption and deactivation of catalysts. As supported by the XRD analysis of spent catalysts, boron oxide doping apparently retarded the serious phase transformation of ZrO2 support, which also contributed to the long-term stability of 3BCu/ZrO2 catalysts. In the most of the literatures focused on hydrogenation of LA to GVL using copper-based catalysts, the optimized GVL yield was achieved at a high temperature above 200 °C for bath reactor [4,8], whereas the temperature applied in a continuous fix-bed reactor was generally no less than 250 °C [27]. Under these reaction temperatures, which were much higher than the Hüttig temperature of copper (134 °C), the surface active copper particles would aggregate readily, resulting in poor lifespan and thermal stability of copper-based catalysts. However, in our work, as high as 96.1% yield of GVL achieved at a considerably low temperature of 140 °C for 3BCu/ZrO2. The mild reaction temperature was conducive to the stability of highly dispersed copper nanoparticles. Thus, the mild temperature, at which the superior catalytic activity was achieved for 3BCu/ZrO2, was in turn benefit for its long-term stability. 5 Conclusions The introduction of a suitable amount of boron oxide into Cu/ZrO2 was demonstrated to pronouncedly improve the catalytic activity as well as stability for hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Among the series of boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2, 3BCu/ZrO2 gave the best catalytic performance. It achieved a full conversion of LA with 100% GVL yield at 150 °C low temperature, even an as high as 96.1% yield of GVL was obtained at a considerably low temperature of 140 °C, which was almost the best results ever reported for hydrogenation of LA catalyzed by copper-based catalysts. Furthermore, 3BCu/ZrO2 achieved a stable performance for 100 h with GVL yield up to 90% in continuous fix-bed reaction, indicating the potential for industrial applications in a large scale. The addition of boron oxide retarded the growth of copper nanoparticles, improved the dispersion of copper and copper surface area due to the strong interaction of boron oxide with surface copper species. Doping boron oxide also inhibited phase transformation of ZrO2 support during LA hydrogenation reaction. These effects of boron oxide were predominantly responsible for the outstanding catalytic activity and lifespan of boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. Moreover, doping boron oxide also increased specific surface area, modulated distribution of surface Cu0 and Cu+, facilitated adsorption of H2, and improved surface acidity of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, which played a positive role on the catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Cu/ZrO2 has been recently demonstrated as a promising non-precious metal catalyst for the efficient hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL), while suffering from insufficient catalytic activity and stability with relatively high reaction temperature (up to 200 °C). Herein, a series of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts modified with boron oxide was prepared and applied for hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The introducing boron oxide effectively improved the activity and lifespan of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst for hydrogenation of LA into GVL. The optimal 3BCu/ZrO2 catalyst afforded complete LA conversion along with 100% GVL yield at 150 °C low temperature. Besides, 3BCu/ZrO2 showed outstanding long-term stability and ran stably with GVL yield up to 90% for at least 100 h in continuous fix-bed tests, making it a promising catalyst of industrial applications for LA hydrogenation. Furthermore, the boron oxide doped and free Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were fully characterized by using ICP, BET, N2O titration, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR/TPD, and NH3-TPD. Boron oxide strongly interacted with surface copper species, which in turn restrained the aggregation of copper particles and improved the copper dispersion during thermal treatment and reaction. The strong interaction of boron oxide with surface copper species mainly accounted for the excellent catalytic activity and stability of boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. Besides, doping boron oxide also increased specific surface area, modulated distribution of surface Cu0 and Cu+, facilitated adsorption of H2, and improved surface acidity of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, which also played positive roles on the catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective synthesis of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid at mild conditions catalyzed by boron oxide doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts
